events.title: First Continental Congress Convenes
events.description: The First Continental Congress met in Philadelphia, bringing together delegates from twelve of the thirteen colonies to respond to British policies.
events.significance: This was a critical step leading to American independence, as colonies coordinated efforts against British rule.

events.title: Tsar Peter the Great's Grand Embassy Departs
events.description: Tsar Peter I of Russia set out on the Grand Embassy, a diplomatic mission to western Europe to seek allies against the Ottoman Empire and to learn about shipbuilding and modern technologies.
events.significance: This mission marked Peter's push to modernize Russia and expand its influence.

events.title: Munich Massacre Begins
events.description: On the second day of the 1972 Summer Olympics in Munich, members of the Palestinian group Black September took Israeli athletes hostage, leading to a tragic hostage crisis.
events.significance: The event brought international attention to terrorism and had profound effects on Olympic security protocols.

events.title: First televised presidential debates in the US
events.description: On September 5, 1960, the first-ever presidential debate between John F. Kennedy and Richard Nixon was held, marking a turning point in political communication with its emphasis on television.
events.significance: This debate influenced the importance of television and media presence in political campaigns.

events.title: Albert Einstein's Annus Mirabilis Paper Published
events.description: Einstein's paper on the photoelectric effect, which proposed the quantum nature of light, was published, a key development in modern physics.
events.significance: This work earned Einstein the Nobel Prize and laid foundations for quantum theory.
